steps.title: Select a granite-safe polish.
steps.content: Select a granite-safe polish. General polishes may damage the surface if they contain ammonia, bleach, or vinegar. [1] X Research source You can buy wet or dry polish. Dry powder (which you mix with water) can be better at removing scratches and is less expensive. [2] X Research source Don't use any harsh chemicals or products to polish your granite.

steps.title: Clean the granite with warm water and dish soap.
steps.content: Clean the granite with warm water and dish soap. Using a dish cloth, gently wipe the stone to remove dirt or debris. Use a mild pH-neutral dish soap without ammonia or bleach. Harsh chemicals could strip away sealant. [3] X Research source Always clean the granite's surface before you start polishing it.

steps.title: Spray granite polish or cleaner over the entire area.
steps.content: Spray granite polish or cleaner over the entire area. Soap is good for cleaning but can leave granite looking dull so a stone-specific polish will restore shine. Never use a gritty or coarse product as this might scratch the surface or eat at the sealant. [4] X Research source Less is more. Only use the recommended amount of polish (read the box as using too much will leave a dull residue. A thorough cleaning should be done once a week to make your stone sparkle. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Dry the granite completely.
steps.content: Dry the granite completely. Leaving product or water on the surface can cause streaks or stains. [6] X Research source Use a soft cloth or paper towel to wipe away excess liquid.

steps.title: Buff with a dry microfiber towel.
steps.content: Buff with a dry microfiber towel. A microfiber cloth contains tiny split fibers that make it more absorbent than cotton, meaning it will soak up leftover residue instead of just smearing it around. [7] X Research source Rub in small circles with firm pressure.

steps.title: Check to see if your granite needs to be resealed.
steps.content: Check to see if your granite needs to be resealed. To do this, put a few drops of water on your countertop. If it leaves a watermark or soaks into the stone, you should seal your granite . [8] X Research source You should seal granite after polishing for best results. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Mix rubbing alcohol, dish soap, and water in a spray bottle.
steps.content: Mix rubbing alcohol, dish soap, and water in a spray bottle. Pour 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) of rubbing alcohol into a 16 oz (450 g) bottle, then add a few drops of dish soap. Fill the rest of the bottle with water. [10] X Research source Shake to combine. Use a dish soap that doesn't have antibacterial additives which can leave streaks on the surface of the granite. [11] X Research source You can swap the dish soap for castile soap for a more environmentally-friendly alternative. Store your spray at room temperature. It should last for 1 to 2 months. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Spray the polish on your granite.
steps.content: Spray the polish on your granite. Make sure you've cleaned any spills or sticky residue off the surface with a damp cloth before spraying or it won't be as effective. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Dry thoroughly with a clean towel.
steps.content: Dry thoroughly with a clean towel. You don't need to rinse with water - simply buff the area with a soft microfiber towel, making sure not to leave excess cleaner on the granite. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Shape the edges with a power sander.
steps.content: Shape the edges with a power sander. Use a 40 or 60 grit sandpaper disc to even out the edges. A finer grit sandpaper (like 120 or 150 grit) will work if the edges just need minor shaping. [15] X Research source Always wear a dust mask and safety glasses to protect yourself when using a power sander.

steps.title: Wipe the edges with a damp cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the edges with a damp cloth. This will remove any debris or particles left over from the sanding.

steps.title: Continue sanding with a finer grit sandpaper.
steps.content: Continue sanding with a finer grit sandpaper. Once your edges are shaped, you'll want to use a small 600 grit sandpaper to put on the finishing touches and smooth out the texture. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Apply polishing spray to the granite.
steps.content: Apply polishing spray to the granite. Use a microfiber towel to buff into the surface and dry. Granite typically takes at least 12 hours to dry completely. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Seal the edges.
steps.content: Seal the edges. This will protect the granite and make it easier to clean. [18] X Research source When sealing granite , keep in mind that the edges will often require 2 applications of sealant. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Seal your granite once a year.
steps.content: Seal your granite once a year. Unsealed stone is more vulnerable to stains. In areas that get used a lot or are exposed to water frequently (like around a sink), have a professional reseal the granite annually. Sealant in lower-use areas can last up to 10 years if cared for properly. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Use coasters or placemats for food and drinks.
steps.content: Use coasters or placemats for food and drinks. Letting food that has dyes or oils in it sit on granite will often cause stains. [21] X Research source Always use a cutting board when cooking, too, instead of placing food directly on the counter. Heat can also harm granite so don't put hot pots or pans directly on the stone. Use a trivet or hot pad. If you have granite floors, lay down some rugs to minimize grit being etched into the stone from being walked on.

steps.title: Wipe down granite daily.
steps.content: Wipe down granite daily. It’s not necessary to use a cleaner on your stone every day but simply wiping it with a dry cloth can remove grime and any spills, avoiding permanent stains or scratches. [22] X Research source Vacuum floors often, as well. Make sure your vacuum isn't dragging on the surface or scratching it.
